speech: Mr Chairman Sir Mr Charles Chong asked why we are so obsessed with always being the best in the world

speech: Sir it is my fervent belief that we must maintain this obsession and I use the word obsession without apology

speaker: D
speech: Sir maintaining a number one position for us is not an end in itself but a means to an end

speaker: D
speech: If I can use our sea-port as an example why do we push and why do we strive to keep the port of Singapore a number one container port a number one port in terms of shipping and so on

speaker: D
speech: Sir to remain the number one port is not just a matter of collecting accolades which all Singaporeans can be proud of

speaker: D
speech: Sure we are proud to be the number one port in the world

speaker: D
speech: But more importantly is that with this achievement comes not only pride but also very very tangible benefits

speaker: D
speech: Economically the port creates jobs and it creates wealth for our people

speaker: D
speech: There're seven thousand workers directly employed by the PAS there're another thirty eight thousand employed in industries which are related to the port

speaker: D
speech: Last year or in nineteen ninety the PAS contributed something like two percent to the national wealth

speaker: D
speech: And if we add the port-related industries warehousing ship- etcetera the contribution rises to something like three to four percent of the national wealth

speaker: D
speech: So this is something like one quarter of the transport and communications sector's contribution to the national economy

speaker: D
speech: So it's not just not not just a matter of being number one for its own sake but striving to be the best

speech: And in the process finding that we are the best in the world we are number one in the world and trying to maintain that position

speaker: D
speech: There is no reason for us to feel apologetic about it

speech: I think if we can do it we should continue to try for it

speech: But I have to add that this is not going to be plain-sailing

speech: Sir Mr Charles Chong also asked about our uh liberal open skies policy

speaker: D
speech: I think it is a well-known fact that we have consistently adopted such a policy

speaker: D
speech: Basically what it means is that while we negotiate air rights on a bilateral basis with different countries we want to have as many of these bilateral agreements as possible

speaker: D
speech: Once such an agreement is concluded we allow the other countries airline to fly to Singapore even if our national carrier has no immediate plans to fly to that country

speaker: D
speech: Now why do we do this

speaker: D
speech: The reason is very simple

speaker: D
speech: It brings us many benefits

speaker: D
speech: It enhances tourism visitors from all parts of the world can get in and out of Singapore quickly and conveniently encourages investment it benefits trade and most of all consumers will benefit from a wider choice of airlines and more convenient itineraries

speaker: D
speech: Now I sometimes like to think of our airport as a huge bus interchange with flights coming in and out at such frequent intervals that sometimes people would rather come to Singapore catch a flight and then go on to their final destination destination rather than go directly because it is faster and sometimes it's even cheaper to do it the this way

speaker: D
speech: So while we continue to adopt this open skies policy I must mention the fact that it does not mean that Singapore is prepared to give away more than what we actually receive

speaker: D
speech: And in this respect whenever we have an air services negotiation it is the overall package of exchange that must be an equitable one

speaker: D
speech: and when I say equitable I'm talking about there being a balance of opportunities

speaker: D
speech: Not a balance of benefit but a balance of opportunities for both sides

speaker: D
speech: And the reason why we ask for a balance of opportunities is simply because we know that under such a situation we can compete with the best in the world
